comments.commentBody: “Financialization” in the articles context is a smarty replacement for "Wall Street" and it includes industries that have a deep and integral part of the economy, but it isn't the catalyst of growth.  Instead it is a set of tool that fuels growth by putting ideas into production.  All these graphs and assumption based on obscure studies doesn't explain how things actually work.  Mr. Bartlett quotes David Stockman who sums it all up as "a giant casino", really.  If policies were conducive to harnessing the return of ideas (investments) then there is growth and then there are jobs.  In this area Bartlett has it all backwards.

Proving once again why you're employed by the Times and I am just an unverified commenter:

Using C.C. like a professional degree (or certification, for that matter)! Perfect! And very appropriate for this time of year, with school ending.

The great thing about C.C. as a degree/certification is you can make the phrase sound as fancy as you want, while keeping the same letters.

Like "Baccalaureate Artis" instead of "Bachelor of Arts"; it's still B.A.

Thanks, Professor!

We need to make an important distinction here:  The EXISTENCE of a massive government program collecting metadata on the communications of US citizens without probable cause needs to be publicly debated.  Attempting to classify the existence of the program makes any meaningful debate impossible and is a complete perversion of the democratic process.  The DETAILS and results obtained from that collection should (and in fact must) remain classified.  Mr. Snowden appears to understand this distinction, and if that indeed proves to be the case, he should be treated as a whistleblower and not a traitor.

Thank god Snowden "subverted" the process. If those that signed the "Declaration of Independence" hadn't we would all be saying "God Save the Queen". We are a national founded on a group of malcontent anarchist least we forget.

H.B.: I'm a Yellow Dog Democrat. I was a Hillary supporter because she was the most qualified candidate. That said, Obama got the nomination and I voted for him in both general elections.

He is the president. The buck stops at his desk. Yes, President George Bush started this awful program. But President Obama could have stopped it. He chose not to stop it. Obama chose to expand the program of domestic spying on Americans.

And Obama is no more of a target of a conspiracy in this whistle blowing than President Nixon was when Watergate was revealed. I helped form one of the 1st Impeach Nixon headquarters in Chicago's Hyde Park.

I didn't like Nixon at all, I had campaigned for George McGovern. Still, it gave me no pleasure to have to try to impeach Nixon.

But Nixon violated his oath of office to defend the Constitution and instead violated it, and betrayed his fellow Americans.

I feel as betrayed by President Obama as I did by Nixon. That is simply awful. But Obama has violated his oath of office to defend the Constitution and he has violated it with domestic spying that violates our Constitutional right to protection from unreasonable searches. And he has done it based on the premise that someday in the future some of us might do something wrong, which is a violation of our Constitutional right to be presumed innocent.

I don't know where this is going to end. But I do feel that our nation's survival as a free country is imperiled. And that is not acceptable.

Can't claim to have seen MUSCLY in print, but I smiled when I wrote it in because it's definitely the kind of word I'd use in conversation if I needed it.

Just for fun I went to Ngrams and checked it out:
http://books.google.com/ngrams

I entered muscley,muscly

"Muscly" was in vogue around 1804 and has been climbing again since the 1970s. While the figures are teensy, it's beating the pants off "muscley."

Leapy, really!

Are you thinking steroids?

DeadlineDH,

I was thinking of sweet Molly Malone. Really.
On the whole, this was pleasant. But "muscly"? Really?
Interesting premise. The Us has offered sanctuary to "political dissidents" for far less.
Isn't that what the pilgrims did?

"The opposition needs to form a unified front with a common platform in order to have a chance at winning." What will they win for stepping forward? A prison term under 301?
Population/number wise there are too many uninformed citizens (& with a lock on the media how will they ever be informed?) who will go along with the status quo.
The constitution will be changed by Edrogan's party (the majority) in the legislature, a new office of president will be instituted and Erdogan will be another Mubarak style dictator for life.
Trampling the rights of the people is tyranny.
Who can any longer call this a democracy?

c2396: Fantastically spot-on analogy!!!
You'd better pray we do.  Canada already has.  It now requires Mexicans to have visas because too many were coming to Canada then applying for asylum to take advantage of your generous benefits.

Gerry,

Gee guy, I disagree. Unless I read it wrong.

There are many South, Central, Mexican Americans
who have relocated into Canada instead of
stopping in the United States.
===
We used to, (in the old days), refer to these peoples
as 'Nomads".

They, (like the gypsies that Hitler eliminated), merely
live where they want to.

That becomes a problem for various Governments
because they base their Authority upon Geography.

Hamlets, Townships, Towns, Cities, Counties, States,
and Nations, all have Restrictive Governments who
conflict with the normal activities of Nomads.

Life would be funny, but it's not.

Whether conservative or liberal. we have both noticed once you have made the north American border. Shut the door.
Not likely.
Obama should hand over his unearned Nobel peace prize to Snowden and wish him well.
John, I think you should talk to the ACLU about this episode, it sounds like it could potentially help with one or more court cases against the NSA.

So Snowden is a felon because he told that the NSA is spying on innocent, private citizens? The balance between "national security interests" and privacy has been crossed, Professor, by the government thanks to the Patriot Act. I'm a private citizen -- not a terrorist -- and my privacy and ability to conduct PERSONAL business was halted thanks to the NSA. Here's a real life example: In November 2008, I started searching online for flights to a trip to Ireland my wife and I were making in March 2009. Also in November 2008, my "Self-Directed Roth Individual Retirement Account" which I named (unimaginatively) S-D RIRA sought to move money from its account in California to purchase land in Georgia. The Federal Government BLOCKED the wire transfer of the closing funds for 3 days so that they could confirm that S-D RIRA did no mean "Sean and David's Irish Republican Army." That is what the banker told me when I inquired as to why the delay in the wire transfer of MY money.

If some govt. agency weren't spying how did they put those two pieces of info together and how in the world would the Feds even possible consider that S-D IRA might have ANYTHING to do with the Irish Republic Army?

The scales have tipped, sir, and not in favor of law-abiding private citizens. The Patriot Act and all the activity it spawned is a greater threat to our freedom than any terrorist.

In the context of traditional Chinese moral or ethical order, what Mr. Snowden did is  almost unforgivable, and I would serious doubt if any parents would want their children to emulate Mr. Snowden's actions.   I would be surprised if there would be popular demand among HK residents  for the government to help Mr. Snowden avoid facing the consequences of his actions.

Well, HB, I don't think my government has a right to do the following:

In November 2008, I started searching online for flights to a trip to Ireland my wife and I were making in March 2009. Also in November 2008, my "Self-Directed Roth Individual Retirement Account" which I named (unimaginatively) S-D RIRA sought to move money from its account in California to purchase land in Georgia. The Federal Government BLOCKED the wire transfer of the closing funds for 3 days so that they could confirm that S-D RIRA did no mean "Sean and David's Irish Republican Army." That is what the banker told me when I inquired as to why the delay in the wire transfer of MY money.

If some govt. agency weren't spying how did they put those two pieces of info together and how in the world would the Feds even possible consider that my S-D IRA might have ANYTHING to do with the Irish Republic Army? I'm not Irish American... I have no history of communicating with ANY terrorist organization.

The scales have tipped, sir, and not in favor of law-abiding private citizens. The Patriot Act and all the activity it spawned is a greater threat to our personal freedom than any terrorist. Snowden just turned a spotlight on it.

The events of 9/11 will go down as the moment when the United States lost its way and began its decline, as all great nations have done.

I think that was the goal OSB had in mind.

Thank you for the responses.

To Andy Hain: the data center was always identified as an NSA operation, not an IRS center.

To rockyboy: I agree that the US has had a long history of mischief and mayhem in the world, all in the name of spreading democracy. What is different about the post-9/11 world is that we citizens have now accepted that there is no real need for democracy at home and although we have happily trashed human rights abroad, now we trash them at home. According to recent polls, this is OK with a majority of Americans, all in the name of homeland security.

To Matt: I love your optimism. President Obama shares it. However, federal bureaucracy once entrenched is hard to take down, even for a president that wants to end the endless war on terror.

A president, or should I say permanent commander, now simply has too much power and control of an ever larger government apparatus. The office is second in the constitution to the Congress, not primary.

The program is also an enormous waste of resources, both electrical and financial. I suppose we could consider the NSA surveillance activity as a huge jobs program, yet we in Utah have not heard that once that data center is built that many people will be employed. The Utah state legislature did find a way to profit from the NSA -- it passed a law that puts a 6% tax on the electricity the center will use. We have yet to learn if taxing the federal government is possible.

I would have preferred a WPA-type jobs program.

I am surprised at all the sudden focus on this, as if it were news. Wired magazine did a story a couple of years ago about the Utah data center and its purpose was clearly stated. And everytime the subject has come up in the NY Times I have commented with info about the data center. What did everyone think the NSA was going to do with a few million servers?

The events of 9/11 will go down as the moment when the United States lost its way and began its decline, as all great nations have done.

So the sole reference for your affirmation that the NSA's surveillance activities are constitutional is the opinion of Charles Lane, Esq., "a Post editorial writer, specializing in economic policy, financial issues and trade".

Right, I'm sure his mastery of the subject far surpasses the collective expertise of the ACLU, Electronic Frontier Foundation, Government Accountability Project, and a coalition of 83 other civil liberties organizations and Internet companies which hold the opposite view: https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2013/06/86-civil-liberties-groups-and-inte...

And what may I ask is the source of your definition of a whistleblower? Naively trusting my dictionary's definition, I assumed that a whistleblower was in fact an individual who - just like Snowden - makes public disclosure of what in his judgment constitutes wrongdoing.

Whistleblowing would certainly be a lot easier if it entailed no risk and caused no discomfort to anyone, but then it would be rather pointless, wouldn't it?

If instead Snowden had just followed your advice, let me picture the screaming headlines in the newspapers, the breaking news ticker on CNN: "NSA contractor resigns, argues for changes to procedural safeguards!"

The oaths are important and violating the oaths does make work that must be concealed impossible. But what is the value of concealing destructive behaviors by persons in secret programs who don't seem able to see any harm in it?

It's a dilemma. We do not want adversaries who would do violence to us know what we know about them until we capture or neutral them. At the same time, we do not want our limited and valuable resources wasted on endeavors that cannot offer significant benefits except by random happenstance, either. We do not want innocent people drawn into counter terrorist activities which do not afford any ability for them to free themselves before their lives are ruined. We want our government to use all it's resources to deal with real threats not diluting them trying to anticipate future threats by future adversaries by snooping through the lives of unsuspecting people who are just living their lives in hopes of detecting a future Al Qaeda like group or a lone mass murderer.
How can someone subvert a secret process in secret?  It is like a tree falling and nobody hears it.

Tell us about your dating history, Leapy, said everyone.

Feel free not to disclose, said I.

It was worth the wait! I hope this is just beginning!

Snowden is a traitor ,he took the oath of secrecy
and broke it. He should have been prepared to take the consequences of his actions but no , very curiously he runs away to Hong kong .Why Hongkong in China's hands.

I would like to know why, if the NSA has so much information on foreign emails, they can't shut down the Nigerian scammers who want my bank account numbers and Internet passwords so they can send me my lottery winnings for lotteries I never heard of or entered.   They are every bit as frightening to me as terrorists.  Do something useful with all that information.
Lot of information about an individual is available on internet . Are you fighting it?. Snowden broke the law and deserves the punishment.It is that simple
